thread.title: ​What sectors would be most affected by Brexit? | Devon Live
thread.title_full: ​What sectors would be most affected by Brexit? | Devon Live

author: Debora Aru
title: ​What sectors would be most affected by Brexit? | Devon Live
text:
​What sectors would be most affected by Brexit? By HannahFinch | Posted: March 30, 2017 By By Debora Aru 0 COMMENTS SHARES Donald Tusk has Theresa May's letter in his hand. But what will Brexit mean for us? ​What sectors would be most affected by Brexit? X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Car-making and other manufacturing will be the industries most affected by Brexit in the South West. By triggering Article 50, PM Theresa May officially started the formal process of leaving the European Union, which will lead Great Britain out of the European single market. 
Official figures show 41% of exports from the South West currently end up in the EU. The South West exported £21.5bn globally in 2016, and £8.9bn of that came from trade with the European Union. 
Car-making, which accounts for almost two-third of the total exports, or 69%, is likely to suffer more from Brexit. In 2016, the South West exported machinery and transport equipment with a £14.9bn worth. 
Other manufacturing industries - such as prefabricated buildings, sanitary, furniture, footwear, professional, scientific and controlling instruments and apparatus - account for 12% of the total exports from England or £2.6bn. 
Given that the government will be spending months trying to work out new post-Brexit trading arrangements with Europe, where could be possible alternative markets for the South West? 
North America is currently the second biggest trade partner. In 2016, exports to the North America accounted for 18% of the £21.5bn of global exports, or £3.8bn worth. 
On Wednesday, during a press conference, the White House spokesman told reporters that Donald Trump was "a leader in the effort to call for Brexit". That would appear to put Great Britain in a strong position to boost trade with the North America in case of a so-called "hard Brexit". 
In 2016, the UK exported goods globally worth £290.7bn, 49% of which ends up in the European Union, or £142.9bn. England's exports account for three quarters of the total, worth £221.1bn, with 48% of that from trade with European countries, or £106.8bn. 
Car-making industries accounted for the most exports to the EU, 41%, or £119.4bn. Manufacturing industries - such as prefabricated buildings, sanitary, furniture, footwear, professional, scientific and controlling instruments and apparatus - followed, accounting for 14% of £290.7bn, £41.9bn worth. 
North America is the next biggest trade partner. In 2016, England exported £51bn worth of goods to the North America, or 18% of £290.7bn. 
Figures in £ million - Exports by SITC

1 Beverages and Tobacco // 124
